natural problem: How many $4$-digit numbers have the last digit equal to the sum of the first two digits?
natural solution: To make such a number, we'd start with the last digit.
We'd then consider different combinations of the first two digits that give us this sum.

We always have $10$ choices for the third digit. \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Last digit} & \text{First two digits} \\ \hline 0 & - \\ \hline 1 & 10 \\ \hline 2 & 11,20 \\ \hline 3 & 12,21,30 \\ \hline
\] The third digit can be any of the $10$ digits. The answer is $(1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9)\times 10=\boxed{450}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count_numbers :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. count_numbers n = card {m::nat. 1000 \<le> m \<and> m \<le> 9999 \<and> (m mod 10) = ((m div 1000) + ((m div 100) mod 10))}"
shows  "count_numbers 4 = 450"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many $4$-digit numbers have the last digit equal to the sum of the first two digits? The final Answer is 450
 ### Proof
 To make such a number, we'd start with the last digit.
 We'd then consider different combinations of the first two digits that give us this sum.
 We always have $10$ choices for the third digit. \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Last digit} & \text{First two digits} \\ \hline 0 & - \\ \hline 1 & 10 \\ \hline 2 & 11,20 \\ \hline 3 & 12,21,30 \\ \hline
 4 & 13,22,31,40 \\ \hline 5 & 14,23,32,41,50 \\ \hline 6 & 15,24,33,42,51,60 \\ \hline 7 & 16,25,34,43,52,61,70 \\ \hline 8 & 17,26,35,44,53,62,71,80 \\ \hline 9 & 18,27,36,45,54,63,72,81,90 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] The third digit can be any of the $10$ digits. The answer is $(1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9)\times 10=\boxed{450}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes count_numbers :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. count_numbers n = card {m::nat. 1000 \<le> m \<and> m \<le> 9999 \<and> (m mod 10) = ((m div 1000) + ((m div 100) mod 10))}"
shows  "count_numbers 4 = 450"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many four-digit numbers have a sum of the first two digits equal to the last digit? The final answer is 450.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes four_digit_numbers :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "four_digit_numbers = {x | x. 1000 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 9999}"
and h1 : "card {x \<in> four_digit_numbers. last_digit x = sum_first_two_digits x} = 450"
shows  "card {x \<in> four_digit_numbers. last_digit x = sum_first_two_digits x} = 450"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many $4$-digit numbers have the last digit equal to the sum of the first two digits? The final Answer is 450

 We always have $10$ choices for the third digit. \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Last digit} & \text{First two digits} \\ \hline 0 & - \\ \hline 1 & 10 \\ \hline 2 & 11,20 \\ \hline 3 & 12,21,30 \\ \hline
 4 & 13,22,31,40 \\ \hline 5 & 14,23,32,41,50 \\ \hline 6 & 15,24,33,42,51,60 \\ \hline 7 & 16,25,34,43,52,61,70 \\ \hline 8 & 17,26,35,44,53,62,71,80 \\ \hline 9 & 18,27,36,45,54,63,72,81,90 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] The third digit can be any of the $10$ digits. The answer is $(1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9)\times 10=\boxed{450}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes four_digit_numbers :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "four_digit_numbers = {x | x. 1000 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 9999}"
and h1 : "card {x \<in> four_digit_numbers. last_digit x = sum_first_two_digits x} = 450"
shows  "card {x \<in> four_digit_numbers. last_digit x = sum_first_two_digits x} = 450"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 450 four-digit numbers in which the last digit is equal to the sum of the first two digits. Find the total number of such numbers. The final answer is 450.

fixes count_4digit_numbers :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. count_4digit_numbers n = card {abcd . 1000 \<le> abcd \<and> abcd < 10000 \<and> abcd mod 10 = (abcd div 1000) + ((abcd div 100) mod 10)}"
shows  "count_4digit_numbers 4 = 450"

a_3.informal problem: How many 4-digit numbers have the property that the sum of their first two digits is equal to the sum of their last two digits? The final answer is 450.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>n. 1000 * (n div 1000) + 100 * (n mod 1000 div 100) + 10 * (n mod 100 div 10) + n mod 10)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<longrightarrow> (n mod 10 = (n div 1000) + (n mod 1000 div 100))"
shows  "card {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<and> h1 n} = 450"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many $4$-digit numbers have the last digit equal to the sum of the first two digits? The final Answer is 450
 ### Proof
 To make such a number, we'd start with the last digit.
 We'd then consider different combinations of the first two digits that give us this sum.
 We always have $10$ choices for the third digit. \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Last digit} & \text{First two digits} \\ \hline 0 & - \\ \hline 1 & 10 \\ \hline 2 & 11,20 \\ \hline 3 & 12,21,30 \\ \hline
 4 & 13,22,31,40 \\ \hline 5 & 14,23,32,41,50 \\ \hline 6 & 15,24,33,42,51,60 \\ \hline 7 & 16,25,34,43,52,61,70 \\ \hline 8 & 17,26,35,44,53,62,71,80 \\ \hline 9 & 18,27,36,45,54,63,72,81,90 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] The third digit can be any of the $10$ digits. The answer is $(1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9)\times 10=\boxed{450}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>n. 1000 * (n div 1000) + 100 * (n mod 1000 div 100) + 10 * (n mod 100 div 10) + n mod 10)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<longrightarrow> (n mod 10 = (n div 1000) + (n mod 1000 div 100))"
shows  "card {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<and> h1 n} = 450"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the number of four-digit integers $n$ such that the last digit (unit's place) of $n$ is equal to the sum of the first two digits (thousand's and hundred's places). The final answer is 450.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<and> f n = (n mod 10) - ((n div 1000) + ((n div 100) mod 10))"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<longrightarrow> (f n = 0) = (\<exists>k. k \<ge> 1 \<and> k \<le> 450 \<and> n = 1000 + 110 * k)"
shows  "card {k. k \<ge> 1 \<and> k \<le> 450 \<and> (\<exists>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<and> n = 1000 + 110 * k)} = 450"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many $4$-digit numbers have the last digit equal to the sum of the first two digits? The final Answer is 450
 ### Proof
 To make such a number, we'd start with the last digit.
 We'd then consider different combinations of the first two digits that give us this sum.
 We always have $10$ choices for the third digit. \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Last digit} & \text{First two digits} \\ \hline 0 & - \\ \hline 1 & 10 \\ \hline 2 & 11,20 \\ \hline 3 & 12,21,30 \\ \hline
 4 & 13,22,31,40 \\ \hline 5 & 14,23,32,41,50 \\ \hline 6 & 15,24,33,42,51,60 \\ \hline 7 & 16,25,34,43,52,61,70 \\ \hline 8 & 17,26,35,44,53,62,71,80 \\ \hline 9 & 18,27,36,45,54,63,72,81,90 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] The third digit can be any of the $10$ digits. The answer is $(1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9)\times 10=\boxed{450}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<and> f n = (n mod 10) - ((n div 1000) + ((n div 100) mod 10))"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<longrightarrow> (f n = 0) = (\<exists>k. k \<ge> 1 \<and> k \<le> 450 \<and> n = 1000 + 110 * k)"
shows  "card {k. k \<ge> 1 \<and> k \<le> 450 \<and> (\<exists>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 9999 \<and> n = 1000 + 110 * k)} = 450"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: For all integers n between 1000 and 9999, consider a function f(n) = (n % 10) - ((n // 1000) + ((n // 100) % 10)). Find the number of integers k between 1 and 450 such that there exists an integer n between 1000 and 9999 where f(n) = 0 and n = 1000 + 110 * k. The final answer is 450.

fixes count_four_digit_numbers :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"

 \] The third digit can be any of the $10$ digits. The answer is $(1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9)\times 10=\boxed{450}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes count_four_digit_numbers :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: How many four-digit numbers have the property that the sum of their first two digits (from left) equals the last digit? The final answer is 450.
